projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Thirty Years' War, 1618-1648 -- Sources -- Early works to 1800.

2014-02 Kate AllenText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: Numb. 6.

A Coranto. RELATING DIVERS PARTICVLARS CONCERNING THE NEWES OVT OF JTALY, Spaine, Turkey, Perſia, Bohemia, Sweden, Poland, Auſtria, the Pallatinates, the Griſons, and diuers places of the Higher and Lower GERMANIE.
Printed for Nathaniel Butter, Nicholas Bourne, and William Shefford, 1622.

div.head: A RELATION OF THIS Weekes newes out of Jtaly, Spaine, Turkey, Perſia, Bohemia, and Sweden, Poland, Auſtria, the Pallatinate, the Hague, and other places of High and Low GERMANY.
From Rome, Octob. 1. 1622.
div.p: FOr the aduancement of the Romane Faith, to be preach't amongſt the Heathen; there are already one thouſand fiue hundred Crownes of yearely penſion, layd vp in ſeuerall places, for the maintenance of thoſe, who will vndertake to be the Apoſtles, and goe to conuert the vnbeleeuing Gentiles.
Laſt Tueſday, the Cardinall Fianardi, dyed of a burning Feauer; he hath giuen great Legacies to his Brethren and friends.
The Cardinall Ludouiſie hath purchaſed the Dukedome of Zaragola, of the Duke of that Place; for 800000. Crownes.

div.head: From Rome, Octob. 7.
div.p: The Archbiſhop of Spalato, who ſince his comming out of England, hath reſyded at Antwerpe, hath long ſince ſubmitted himſelfe to the Holy, Catholique, and Romane Mother-Church. And therefore, there are fiue thouſand Crownes made ouer to him, to defray the charges of his iourney to Rome; the Bils of exchange for the taking vp the money, are with him a good while before this, and hee well onwards on his Iourney, that he may receiue his abſolution from the Popes holineſſe: He hopes well: for whereas before his comming into England, hee had great ſuits in the Court of Rome, nine yeares together; and the Pope, who was his mortall enemy, was alſo to be his Iudge; he made vſe of England, as of a Whoode, to keepe his head from a ſtorme; but ſince by the Popes death, the ſtorme is ouer; he comes now abroad againe into the ſun-ſhine; for his Holineſſe that now is Biſhop of Rome, was ſometimes his Schoole-fellow. It is reported, that he hath made very good vſe of England.

div.head: From Rome, the ſame Date.
div.p: The Bacchieri, (or Banckers) Spinola and Forali, are broken, for ſome thouſands of Crownes.

div.head: From Naples, Octob. 3.
div.p: The Galleyes of Prince Philibert, and thoſe of Biſerta are ſtill out at Sea; the Turkiſh Pyrates, and the Chriſtians, daily lye in waite one for another.

div.head: From Venice, Octob. 5.
div.p: The Collonell Obertrawt, a natiue of the Pallatinate, hauing lyen ſome time at Zuriche, is come hither to offer his ſeruice to this State, eyther to goe backe to ayde the Griſons, or to be imployed elſe-where.

div.head: From Madrill, in Spaine, Octob. 8.
div.p: In the end of September, here dyed that great man of State, who ſtill entertained and diſpatcht ſo many buſineſſes, Don Balthaſar de Zuniga: hee was a great man, and Vncle to the Fauourite, the Count de Oliuarez. Here will be great miſſe of him, for his many good ſeruices: he it was, who was the chiefe Commiſſioner for our King, in the treaty betweene the French Ambaſſador, and the Deputies of the Griſons, about the Valtoline, which he concluded to the great benefit of his Country.

div.head: From Madrill the ſame day.
div.p:
Here is an order giuen out of his Maieſties command, for a great and generall contribution, to be taken by the poll; that is, euery one muſt giue a peece
of eight Reals (which is foure ſhillings Engliſh) towards the warres in Holland, and the charges which his Maieſtie hath beene at, for the Valtoline, and his great Nauy, lately ſet to ſea, two or three ſeuerall wayes.

div.head: From Rome, Octob. 11.
div.p: The Viceroy of Naples hath layd a new Impoſition vpon the Corne and Fruits: which would amount to 80000. Crownes a yeare; which ſhould be a treaſury to allay any ſudden commotions, and to ſupply the King of Spaines preſent want of new Coyne: but for that thoſe that were appointed to be the Collectors, haue refuſed ſuch a thankeleſſe office, the Viceroy hath ſent Poſt into Spaine, to know the Kings reſolution therein.

div.head: From Madrill.
div.p: Wee heare for certaine, that the Count de Gondomar, late Ambaſſador in England, ſhall returne thither againe the next Spring, but whether as ordinary or extraordinary, is not yet knowne.
The ſame is confirmed by his owne Letters in Enggland, as ſome Catholiques ſay.

div.head: From Prague Septem. 29.
div.p:
The Archiſynagoga, or Gouernour of the Iewiſh Synagogue, who is called Baſſeri, is lately come
from Vienna, and arriued here, where hee is receiued of his Nation with great honour. For he hauing kept the Iewes true to his Imperiall Maieſtie, all the time of theſe Bohemian troubles (the Iewes better affecting the Catholique Religion, then the reformed,) and hauing largely contributed to the warres of the Emperour: his Maieſtie hath now rewarded him with a Chayne of Gold, weighing one hundred Ducats, and with his owne picture to hang about his necke, with many other Imperiall gifts, and many fauours alſo and new priuiledges to his Nation, both for their perſonall quiet, and the freer exerciſe of their Religion. Hee comming neere to this City with fiue Coaches in his trayne, was met vpon the way with diuers Iewes, both on Horſe and Foote, who conducted him, with great triumph, (after their faſhion) into the Towne, lodging him in their City. Hee was apparrelled after the Hungarian faſhion: His Cloake was of redde Veluet, his Sword and Spurres guilded, and he ware the aforeſaid Chayne about his necke, with the Emperours picture hanging at it.

div.head: From Prague, Septem. 27.
div.p:
The execution of the Bohemian Lords, is now better knowne to be made, for theſe reaſons; and theſe men haue beene, and are to be executed: Firſt, thoſe that were preſent when the other Catholique Lords were thrown out at the window, as they ſate in Councell together, about the putting out of the Emperour,
from being King of Bohemia. Secondly, all thoſe that can be found, to haue beene of confederacie with thoſe that conſpired againſt his Imperiall Maieſtie, and the Houſe of Auſtria. Thirdly, thoſe that were preſent at the reiection of Ferdinand the Emperour. Fourthly, thoſe that were preſent at the election of the Elector Fredericke Count Pallatine.

Fiftly, all thoſe that ſerued in the Campe before Vienna, when that it was blockt vp by the Count Mansfield, or afterward, eyther vnder the Prince of Anholt, the Count Hollocke; or vnder any other his Imperiall Maieſties Enemies and Traytors: What the Iſſue of this will be, time will ſhew.

By this laſt Article, many of the Inferiour ſort of Gentlemen, and the Artificers alſo, are like to be brought in queſtion, who were Souldiers againſt the Emperour at his owne doores, and there is much murmuring.

div.head: From Vienna, Octob. 5.
div.p: The Count of Schellenburgh; who is a Moneth ſince returned out of Turkey, (ſeeing that the great Turke hath reuealed the conſpirators againſt the Emperour, who ſolicited him to ayde them; many of whoſe names are to be ſeene at their owne Letters, which the great Turke alſo ſent: He hath ſubmitted himſelfe and asked pardon of his Maieſtie: but was neuertheleſſe committed to priſon, till hee hath reuealed the reſt of them that authorized him, to goe into Turkey, as their Ambaſſador. Whereupon euery man almoſt feares himſelfe at Prague.

div.head: From Franckford, Octob. 14.
div.p: Here is arriued a Bauarian Commiſſioner in the name of his Imperiall Maieſtie, and his highneſſe of Bauaria; his requeſt is; That the Burgomaſter of our cittie, would permit him to leauy certaine ſouldiers in our towne and thereabouts, for the Emperors ſeruice. And that they might likewiſe be maintained at the charge of the Citizens, and be billetted in their houſes vntill the generall muſter. But the Burgomaſter hath excuſed himſelfe, from granting either of theſe requeſts. By this we ſee that the Emperour hath ſome other emploiment for them, for Monſieur Tilly thinkes himſelfe ſtrong enough in the Palatinate; and thoſe that beſieged Glatz, haue long ſince and often refuſed the aides of ſome thouſands of Coſſacks, who offered them their ſeruice.

div.head: From Franckford, Octob. 16.
div.p:
Although it was written long ſince that thoſe Coſſaks and Crabats which were rambled together about Oppenheim, and had paſſed the Rhine, being of horſe and foot about 7000. beſides many women and children, were to goe towards Sileſia, and had already paſſed on through the Landtgraue of Heſſens and Darmſtadts countries, and ſo to the foreſt of Oldenwaeldt, where they were to goe forwards
(as we then heard) yet it is ſince knowne that to the great griefe of the country thereabouts, they are there ſtill ſtaid: and for that the Princes of the Empire are loath to haue ſo many rude fellowes, paſſe through their countryes, and for that the Emperour findes by experience of others of their Nation, who went before, how he is like to be troubled with them: it is ſaid that they are to be ſent into the low Countries; for that the Spaniſh armie hath had there no good ſucceſſe, and is alſo much weakned in Brabant. Of which laſt part of the newes, it is ſaid that the Prince, Archbiſhop Elector of Cullen, had this word alſo ſent to Hanaw, (where he then lay about October, in his iourney towards the Dyet of Regenſpurg) that theſe Coſſacks were very likely to be ſent into Brabant, to reenforce the Spaniſh companies, which are farre more in the Liſt then they are in the Polle.

div.head: From Prague, Octob. 11.
div.p: Thoſe Coſſacks which before made towards Sileſia, hauing made great ſpoile in that countrey are now fallen backe againe, with an intent (as it is thought) to thruſt themſelues into the Principality of Glogau.

div.head: From Ladenburg in the Palatinate, Octob. 14.
div.p: The two brothers the Counts of Wiedt, are at great diſſention, and daily way-lay one another, ſo that all the paſſages hereabouts, are very dangerous to paſſe; and eſpecially for thoſe merchants who ſtaid late at Franckford Mart, and are to trauell this way.

div.head: From Mentz. Octob. 15.
div.p: There is likely to bee verie good Rheniſh wine this Vintage which is now begunne; but it will be verie ſcant, and exceeding deare.

div.head: Out of the Palatinate.
div.p: From hence we heare the ſame things confirmed which we wrote in our former booke printed Nouember 5. concerning Manheim and Franckendale; which we will not heere repeat, for that we will not abuſe you, by ſelling you one thing twice.

div.head: From Cullen, Octob. 21.
div.p: The plague continueth here very hot, for all the cold weather, there die 800, a weeke in this citie, beſides thoſe which die in the townes and villages hereabouts.

div.head: From Stockholme in Sweden, Septemb. 17.
div.p: The long warres betweene the Kings of Poland and Sweden, are for the preſent ceaſed: for there is a truce taken for 10. moneths, of which the King of Sweden hauing before written to his friends, is ſince this, ſafely returned to his Caſtle of Stockholme.

div.head: From Danske, Septemb. 30.
div.p: The King of Poland deſired to haue the Parel Church, where the Lutheranes preached before, at his owne diſpoſing, purpoſing to place a Couent of Friers in it. Their Councell haue met about it, and are to giue an anſwer within 8. daies.

div.head: From Switz, Octob. 7.
div.p: The Archduke Leopoldus hauing ſince the Diet of Lindaw, lien very ſicke at Ruſach, begins now to recouer.

div.head: From the Hage.
div.p:
It was here ſomewhiles ſince reported, that the Duke Chriſtian of Brunſwicke (he that hath beene that noble Champion and companion in armes with Count Mansfield) with his mother the old
Dutches of Brunſwick, haue beene in the end of this ſummer about leauying ſome forces for the King of Bohemiaes ſeruice. But ſince we heare that there is a more generall agreement, of the Northerne Proteſtant kings and Princes of Germany; and that the Kings of Denmarke and Sweden, the Duke Elector of Saxonie, and the Marqueſſe Elector of Brandenburgh, the Duke of Brunſwick, the Landtgraue of Heſſen, and diuers others of their Religion, are about to leauy a common army to reeſtate the Prince Elector Palatine in his countreyes againe: ſeeing that no forraine armes can doe it ſo conueniently; and beſides the example ſo much concernes the libertie of Germany, and the eſtates of the Princes of the Empire, that they beginne to thinke it is not ſafe for them to ſuffer a ſtrange ſouldier to be brought into Germany, which is contrary to the lawes of the Empire in generall, and dangerous to the Princes in particular. The Marqueſſe of Badens cauſe alſo, who for taking part with the King of Bohemiah, is depriued of his upper Marquiſate by the Emperours iudgement: is alſo taken into conſideration.

div.head: From Amſterdam, Octob. 31.
div.p:
It is here reported for certaine; That the Prince the Duke of Brunſwick, who kept his Court at Wolfenbettle in the Land of Brunſwick, is lately dead: So that he dying without iſſue; the Dukedome is fallen to our Noble yong Souldier, Chriſtian of
Brunſwick; who hath by this gotten a Dukedome, after the loſſe of his arme.

div.head: From Conſtantinople, Septemb. 8.
div.p: The new Grand Signior Sultan Muſtapha, prepares mightily for his intended warres againſt the Perſians, and they alſo, doe all that they can to be ready for him: The Turke hath ſtill (for the moſt part) beene thus much before hand with the Perſian; that hee hath marcht with his Armies to viſite him in his owne Countrie, about Tauris or ſome other place. If any thing hinder this Expedition, that he goes not now alſo home to him; it is for that there is a great conſpiracie of diuers Baſhawes againſt their Emperour, there being an hundred thouſand men (as it is ſaid) ready preſt by them againſt their Soueraigne. Thus Perſia and Turkey (who beare the Sunne and the Moone in their Banners) are as like now as euer, to eclipſe one anothers glory. Some ſay that this preſent Sultan hath beene perſwaded, to goe viſite the Tombe of their Prophet Mahomet, at Meccha: and that hee knowes not handſomely how to returne to Conſtantinople, but that his ſimplicitie is by the great Baſhawes and Beglerbegs made vſe of; that while they may rule all at home, he is ſent a Pilgrimage, Meccha being to him little better than an holy priſon.

div.head: From Bruſſels, Octob. 7.
div.p:
Her Highneſſe the Archducheſſe Infanta, with the reſt of her Councell, conſidering the diſhonour
which hereby redounded to the Spaniſh partie, that after the ill ſucceſſe of the Armie before Bergen vp Zoome, ſo many ſouldiers, euen of the naturall Spaniards and Italians, ſhould run from their Colours, and goe ſerue the States her enemies, or elſe goe for their owne Countries; thought good for the puniſhment of thoſe, and the terror of others, that ſhould dare to attempt ſuch an eſcape; to proſcribe ſome fifteene of them by name, the Copie of which proſcription here followeth, tranſlated out of Low Dutch.

opener.signed: Iſabella Clara Eugenia, by the Grace of God, Infanta of Spaine, &c.

body.p:
Whereas wee vnderſtand that Stephano Prena Sergeant of a Band: Ioan Paulo Serin, Sergeant: Vaſalo Sericho, Corporall: Damiano de Michele: Damiano Lorenzo: Bartholomeo de Baſtiano: Lucio San Piero: Bartholomeo Albano: Ioſepho Brocola: Siluio Romano: Vincentio Brilia: Nicolao Lombardo: Iacobo Lorano: Giouanni Piolan, and Dominico de Valentin; are runne ouer to the Enemie, and haue treated with them vpon matters of treaſon, againſt the ſeruice of his Maieſtie: Wee therefore declare and pronounce them to be Traytors; and doe giue withall charge to all the Subiects of his Maieſtie, and to the Souldiers of his Campe, to hold and take them for ſuch; and that they doe all their beſt endeuour to kill them and depriue them of their liues. And whoſoeuer ſhall ſo doe, in what place ſoeuer he can atchieue it, and ſhall haue ſlaine any of them; ſhall giue notice thereof to the Auditour generall; who ſhall giue order, that a thouſand Philips Dollars ſhall be paid vnto him for ſuch his
ſeruice: and moreouer, if he be a Souldier, wee will adnance him, and beſtow the command of a Footcompany vpon him, of thoſe of his owne Nation. Declaring moreouer, that if any of them ſhall kill or make away one another, ouer and aboue the foreſaid recompence, We will pardon him his offence. And to the end that this may come to the knowledge of euery one of them, we haue directed Peter Puteanus, Counceller and Auditor generall of the Campe, that he ſhall cauſe this our commandement to be publiſhed in this Court, and in ſuch other places, where it ſhall ſeeme moſt expedient.

closer.dateline: Giuen at Bruxels the ſeuenth of October 1622.
closer.signed: By her Highneſſe order, Matheo de Vrquina.

postscript.p: Imprinted at Bruxels, by Hubrecht Anthoon, ſworne Booke-Printer of the Court, 1622.

div.p: The Copie of this Proclamation, the Hollanders haue alſo gotten and Imprinted; prefixing alſo a long Diſcourſe, the Summe whereof is this. That this deuice was taken for no other end, then by naming but fifteene only, to make the Boores of their owne Countrey beleeue, that there were no more that came away: whereas the Iournals of Berghen affirme, that they came running by ten, twentie, thirty or more at a time, out of the Campe, into the Towne.

div.head: From Middleborough, Octob. 22.
div.p: NOt long before the Campe of the Prince of Orange brake vp from Roſſendale, the Marqueſſe Spinola ſent a Trumpet to the Prince, with the Rittmaſter, (Captaine of a horſe troope) Abremon, to treat about keeping faire quarter on both ſides; whereas before there had beene ſome violent diſorders committed on both parties, againſt the Law of Armes. Whereupon 15. committees were appointed for each ſide, who met together at a village called Calmpthout betweene Bergen vp Zoome, and Antwerpe: on our ſide, there went among others, the Baron of Sterkenburgh, and the noble Droſſard Brochum. At firſt they could not well agree, ſo that they were ready to depart: but at laſt the matter was brought to this point, That an Earle being taken Priſoner ſhould pay for his ranſome 10000. Gilders, a Campemaſter 1000. a Captaine 600. a Leifetenant 150. an Ancient, Sergeant, horſeman and foot ſoldier, each accordinglie to his pay. Thus was it concluded at Calmpthout, October 16. 1622. and with this the Committees returned to their Quarters.

div.head: From Amſterdam, October 27.
div.p:
THE Spaniſh Forces lie ſtill about the villages of Brabant, and ſome of them haue been ſeen about Venlo in Gelderland, which paſſe there ouer the
bridge, and it was ſaid that more ſhould follow them, but we haue heard no more of them, or that they entended any thing elſe, then to reenforce their Garriſons, and eſpecially to ſtrengthen the towne of Goch.

div.head: From Roſſendale, October 19.
div.p: THE 15. of this moneth, there went ſome horſemen from hence, who fell vpon a Convoy of the enemies, conſiſting of 3. troope of horſe, whereof they killed one of the Captaines, whoſe dead body with 27. priſoners they brought away with them, the which day there went out a party of 80. of our horſemen to Herentall, and paſſed through 180. of the enemies horſe, and tooke 80. of them priſoners, and brought away 33. of them, the reſt ranſomed themſelues. There was the beſt horſe of Grobbendonces troope, called the Gens, taken, they haue gotten 162. Gilders by the ſale of theſe horſes.

The 17. day there were there ſold 58. of the Enemies horſe, with ſaddles, bridles, and piſtols, which were brought from little Brabant. Theſe exploits wee giue you vpon the credit of their owne Lowe Dutch newes.

div.head: From Bergen vp Zoome.
div.p: THE Count Mansfields Souldiers haue catcht the bootehalers which were ſent out by the Conſtable of Hertochen Boſche.

Our Soldiers haue beene nere the towne of Lyer, and haue taken good prize and priſoners, and amongſt the reſt, there was one old cruell man, called
Schapaetien, who had before cauſed many of our ſoldiers to be ſhot to death when they were taken priſoners: this fellow was by our men ſerued likewiſe. And theſe things the Hollanders tell of the actions of their owne men, but impart nothing that ſhould make for the honor of any of Spinolaes, of whoſe doings, they ſuffer vs to knowe little.

div.head: The order and raiſing of the Prince of Orenges Campe from Roſſendale.
div.p: THE order of the Riſing was this; There being many ſhips and boats in a readineſſe to attend: There was firſt ſhipt the greateſt peices of Cannon, and his Excellency with the ſmall peeces of Cannon and ſome falconets marched towards Oudenbergh, many hundreds of ſhips being there in a readineſſe, where one part of our foot went aboard. In the meane time our horſe ſtood ranged in battell array, vntill the foot were ſhipt. After this, his Excellencie being accompanied with many Noblemen, Lords, Rittmaſters, Captaines and other Cavalliers, marched to Breda: where hauing put all things in order, the moſt part of our Cavalliery with his Excellency, and Prince Henry Van Naſſaw, and Count Erneſtus of Naſſaw, beſides many other Noblemen and braue Warriours, with the ſoldiers of Count Mansfield, were by his Excellency ſent higher vpwards, and their Rendezvous was at St. Grauenwert, from whence it was thought, that the horſe might well and ſafely march, as far as into the Biſhopricke of Cullen, and keepe houſe there ſo ratime

The Campe roſe vpon Fryday, and the Wedneſday after, the Prince of Orange returned to the Hagh, being brauely receiued by the foure companyes of Towneſmen. This intelligence although it came ſomething late to our hands, yet we here giue you it, for that it is a good orderly one, and relates many particulars.

div.head: From Amſterdam, October 31.
div.p: THe Horſemen of the States one day amongſt the reſt, brought in a booty valued at 6000. pound ſterling: which made many of their fingers itch, to be doing with the Spaniards alſo: But his Excellency ſaith; that hee will beat them well enough, with lying ſtill.
The King of Bohemia is ſafe returned to the Hagh, and the Duke of Brunſwicke, and Count Mansfield, tooke vp Souldiers for Weſtphalia. The States alſo take vp Souldiers, for all it is towards winter.

div.head: From Berghen and Middleberough.
div.p:
THe Marqueſſe of Baden was arriued at the Hagh, before his Excellency came thither; and ſo likewiſe was the King of Bohemia, and the Count Mansfield, hauing conſulted with the King of Bohemia, about ſome important buſineſſe, and knowing that his Souldiers were already marcht vpwards, tooke his leaue of his Maieſty and the Queene, and went with all ſpeed, together with the Marqueſſe of Baden, to the place where his Souldiers lay: and vnderſtanding
of ſome diſorders committed by ſome of them, he puniſht them with the Strappado, and other bodily puniſhments. Hee is ſince this marcht vpwards.

div.head: From Roſſendale, October 23.
div.p: AFter all this, the Lords the States looking as well to the buſineſſe of the Spaniſh Fleete, as they haue done to their Land Armie, haue taken vp al the ſhips (Merchants and others) that are fit to beare Ordnance, for their ſeruice. And for the ſpeeding of their fleete which they haue put out to ſea, they write from Amſterdam, Octob. 31. That the ſhips of Holland haue lately fought with 5. Spaniſh Carricks, (being of thoſe that went to Argire,) and beat them.

In London alſo the newes is from Plimmoth, that in the end of October, The Hollanders hauing 50. ſayle of ſhips about theſe Seas, haue lately fought with ſome of the Spaniſh Fleete; and with their ſhot ſo rack't through one galleon, that ſhe being no longer able to liue at Sea, put into harbour at Plimmouth, which ſhe had much adoe to recouer without ſincking: and what worke the reſt of the two Feets made one with another, we haue not yet heard off.

div.head: From Amſterdam, October, 20.
div.p: VVEE heare alſo from ſundry places, That the Hollanders haue taken away the Barrels and other Seamarkes, that the Spaniſh Fleete may haue no direction to find their hauens, if they ſhould offer to fall in with any of their coaſts.

But now for the maintenance of this Land Army and great Fleete at Sea, they haue taken the ſame courſe, that the King of Spaine hath done in his dominions, That is, they haue laid a generall Taxation by the polle: for man, woman and child is to giue a Gilder (that is 2. ſhillings Engliſh,) and the 500 pennie beſides of his goods: ſo that he that is worth 500. pound, is to giue 20 ſhillings towards the wars, which will amount to an ineſtimable ſumme of money, for women, children, ſeruants and all muſt pay it. Yea the very poore that receiue Almes alſo, for whom the Collectors muſt pay it, as it is ſaid.

div.head: From Middlebrough, Octob. 26.
div.p:
THE 20. of this month, there happened a moſt lamentable accident, by ſhipping one Oxehead, and two Firkins of Gunpowder, and yet no certaintie can be had how it tooke fire: but ſo it is, that the fire taking it, as it lay vpon the keye ſide, ready to be caried a ſhip-board: It gaue ſuch a cracke: that on both ſides of the hauen, almoſt all the tyles of the houſes, and the glaſſe-windowes, were ſhaken down, and many things within the houſes alſo, throwne
downe and broken. Beſides all this, ſome men, women and chlidren were blowne vp into the aire; ſo that in ſome places farre and neere from thence, was found here an Arme, & there a Leg, here one head, and there another, and in other places, hands, feete, Armes, Hearts, Gutts, Liuers, and other parts of mens bodies; and by it a man burnt to death. In fine, this was ſuch a lamentable ſpectacle to behold, and ſo fearefull, that it cannot be well expreſſed, It is a memorable warning to euery man that is to deale with this damnable Gun powder, to looke to it well and warilie.

Doctor Conradus Vorſtius, a ſubtile Logician and Philoſopher, one of the Fathers and broachers of Arminianiſme, being Profeſſor of Diuinity in the ſchoole of Steinfurt, is lately deceaſed at Connighen.
